captions.text:
Hey, Vsauce, Michael here, and I'm sure that
we all love to have fun with hand shadows,
but how much does a shadow weigh?

It might sound like a silly question, because
it is. I mean, a shadow cannot be put on a

scale and weighed; but, the material that
it falls on top of can be weighed. And,

we know that light has energy. In fact, when
light encounters an object, it pushes that

object just a little bit. On the surface of
Earth, when sunlight is hitting it, every

square inch is being pushed with a force of
about one-billionth of a pound, which is basically

nothing. But, over a large enough surface
area, the results can be pretty fun.

On a sunny day, the city of Chicago weighs
300 pounds more, simply because sunlight is
falling on it, pushing it.

In outer space, where solar wind isn't filtered
by Earth's atmosphere or magnetic field, the

results are even bigger. A space craft, traveling
from Earth to Mars, would be pushed by light

1,000 km off course. So, these things have
to be factored into journeys to Mars. We've

actually already created things that can sail
with light: giant reflective solar sails that
are pushed by the Sun's light.

So, in a way that is calculable, though difficult
to measure, an area covered in shadow technicaly

weighs less than surrounding areas being pushed
by light.

But enough about the Sun. There are 3 astronomical
bodies that can cast shadows on the surface

of Earth bright enough for us humans to see.
One is obviously the Sun, and the other is
the Moon. But, what's the third? Venus.

Pete Lawrence investigated this over a digital
sky. Now, to make sure that the shadow he

saw was caused by Venus, he used a tube that
could be pointed at specific regions in the

sky. Inside the tube, he put a cutout shaped
like the astronomical symbol for Venus.

Now, here is light coming through the tube
when pointed just adjacent to Venus at a point

in the sky relatively dark, and empty, to
the human eye. But here is what came out of

the tube when pointed at Venus: a Venusian
shadow.

We all know that light travels quickly- 299,792,458
m/s=c.

But this light right here, in fact, the light
coming off your screen into your eyeballs

right now, is moving slightly slower than
"c" because "c" is the speed of light in a vacuum,

but all of this light if having to travel
through a medium- in this case air.

The speed of light in air is ever-so slightly
slower than "c"- 298,925,574 m/s. This is

interesting because light travels more slowly
through different materials, but "c" remains

the universal speed limit, and as long as
an object doesn't go that fast, it can still
outpace light in a material.

A charged particle- for instance, an electron-
can travel through water faster than light

does, but never faster than "c". When this
happens, we get something analogous to a sonic
boom. We get a "Photonic Boom."

In a sonic boom, the sound information propagating
off of the object is in the form of compression

waves, and as the object gets closer and closer
to the speed of sound, the speed that those

waves are moving away from it at, each new
wave has less time to get out of the way of

the next until eventually the waves collapse
all into each other and the denisty and pressure
is enormous, causing a sonic boom.

Normally, when a charged particle moves through
a material whose molecules can be polarized,

the molecules give off photons. But each photon
has room to fly away, and the waves all destructively

interfere with each other, so no radiation
is given off.

But, the faster the particle goes, the less
room the photons have away from each other,

and their waves begin to constructively interfere,
giving off a photonic boom: "Cherenkov Radiation."

Astronauts, especially those who have gone
all-the-way to the Moon, have reported seeing

flashes of light. Many people attribute this
to high-speed particles moving through the

liquid inside their eye faster than light
normally would, causing photonic boom's right
inside their body.

Speaking of the speed of light, here's a great
question a few of you have sent me- it involves

a possible way of going faster than "c". Here's
how it goes:

Let's say I want to push a button that is
a lightyear away from me, which means that

it would take light, the fastest possible
thing in the universe, a year just to get
from me to the button.

Ok, well what if I a built board, one lightyear
long, all-the-way from me to the button, and

then I pushed one end of the board- would
the other end immediately push the button?

And, if so, did I just break the speed of
light? Did I just send information faster

than light? Well, we're not talking about
the speed of light anymore, are we? We are
talking about the speed of push.

When you push a rigid object, what you are
really doing is putting a series of compression

waves through the object, which move at the
speed of sound in the object's material.

The information about "whoa, we've been pushed,
you should move," is sent via that compression

wave, and it only travels at the speed of sound.
So, when pushing a normal day-to-day size

type object, it feels almost instantaneous.
But, pushing a lightyear-long board, it would
take a lot longer.

A cool way to see this in action is to look
at an object in which compression waves travel

more slowly. For instance, what Veritasium
has done: blowing minds by showing Slinky's

being dropped. The information telling the
Slinky that "hey, uh, we're moving," travels

through the Slinky slow enough that a slow-mo
camera can see it happen.

If you haven't watched all of Veritasium's
Slinky videos, you've missed out. In fact,

you should watch all of their stuff, it is
superb. But, to wrap things up, here's the

point: the speed of push is not instant, and
it's certainly not the speed of light. But,

light can push you...In fact, technically,
you weigh more when the lights are on than
you do when the lights are off.

I've put links in the description to all kinds
of cool things you should definitely check

out for fun, and for science. And, as always,
thanks for watching.

title: How Much Does a Shadow Weigh?

comments.text:
Just a little thing not pointed out here: The Veritasium slinky isn't 
defying gravity, both ends are moving towards each other. However, the 
bottom end is contracting towards the other end at the same rate it's 
falling. The top seems to move faster because... It is. Gravity is working 
with the top end.

What's interesting though is that the movement on the top end seems to 
travel along the spiraling metal thread of the slinky, instead of the whole 
end moving. That's the part vsauce pointed out.﻿

op hem. Die tweelingbroer is inmiddels 45 jaar oud. In feite is de broer 
die de ruimte heeft verkend dus naar de toekomst gereisd: er zijn maar tien 
jaar verstreken, maar hij arriveert op een aarde die 25 jaar ouder is dan

comments.text:
Here's a thought on breaking the speed of light:
So, you know how lightning will always take the path to ground?
Build 2 separate wires 1 light year long.
On one side, connect on of them to ground. Now, apply an electrical current 
to both wires. If, for example, it goes through the left wire, you know 
that that, 1 light year away, that wire is grounded, and vice versa with 
the right wire.
Therefore, you have transferred information faster than the speed of light.﻿

comments.author: MinecraftEpicPlayer

comments.text:
+MinecraftEpicPlayer How do you apply a current, though? Current is a 
response, more specifically, a net motion of charge carriers in response to 
an applied electric field. You can apply the electric field to both wires, 
yes. But that doesn't mean current just instantly starts flowing along the 
entire length of the grounded wire. Rather, you've just sent a pulse 
through both wires that pushes charge carriers slightly forward until they 
move too close to the ones in front of them. Then those charge carriers get 
pushed forward, bump into their neighbors, and so on, (and this is how the 
pulse travels forward) until the pulse reaches the end. Up until now, there 
has been no difference in the wires. Only when the pulse reaches the end of 
the wire can the charge carriers in the grounded wire escape into your 
ground. Meanwhile, the pulse in the non-grounded wire terminates and the 
entire wire remains at a non-zero potential. Only then is it really 
possible to tell the difference between the two wires. And the pulses 
travel at the speed of propagation of EM waves in the wire - or the speed 
of light in your wire material.

comments.text:
Common misconception about light among people is that-

It's mass less. - Incorrect.
It's not particle, but wave. ( Electromagnetic wave )- Half correct.

The thing is that if something cannot be purely wave or else it will become 
energy and cease to exist in matter form in Universe.

Light is half Matter and half Wave at the same time which gives it dual 
property of Wave and Matter at the same time and also to conserve it's 
energy itself.

Electrons around Atoms also behave like this.

so Vsauce is correct.
Light CAN push you because it has momentum and other half of dual nature 
which gives it a property of matter to act on matter.﻿
comments.author: Ajay Kumar Singh

comments.text:
+Ajay Kumar Singh You're very much mistaken. Yes, the quantum world is very 
strange, but we understand it's principles well.

Particles don't cease to exist randomly, they are transferred to their 
equivalence in energy through either a collision or as a product of their 
unstable decay. This process happens randomly (though we can predict a net 
change over time, e.g. half-life) but the individual cause is well 
understood.

Our understanding of the Universe begins to break down at extreme 
temperatures, pressures, or magnification. This is because of several 
reasons (which are, by the way, not related to this discussion), including 
a lack of unification between relativity and the other forces (E.M. 
Strong/Weak Nuclear force).

It might be possible that there is something that can travel faster than C 
(the speed of light through a vacuum), but there is currently no evidence 
to support it. Particles have been proposed to exist which could possibly 
travel faster than C, but are still hypothetical. This means, with a lack 
of evidence.

Light is the fastest thing in the Universe. It achieves this by being a 
form of pure energy without mass. Light can be converted to mass through 
E=MC^2, this doesn't mean that energy and mass are exactly the same thing 
since they have different properties, they are just related.
Don't mix up these ideas or exclude one another.

comments.text:
+Memori Remov First thing you should know is that MATTER = ENERGY.

This Energy is converted into matter around 14 billion years ago.That event 
is known as Big Bang.

So Matter is just another form of energy that exist.
The Matter make up the Universe.

Matter = Atoms, sub atomic particles, sub-sub atomic particles......till it 
goes back to energy again.

Quantum world still cannot be explained by most physicists and astronomers.

At quantum level particles behave differently.
As they are the last basic unit of Matter and configure directly with 
Energy realm to exist in Universe.

Energy->Sub-sub atomic particles->sub atomic particles->atomic 
particles->Molecules->different States of matter.

A photon is still a particle logically.
Due to some quantum effect it behave as both Matter and Energy.

in other words, we can't detect it's mass due to this property, But it has 
some mass in reality.

It's simply impossible to exist at all in physical world without mass.
Light has mass.

Also mathematically it's impossible for something to exist without mass.

comments.author: Wikiramblings

comments.text:
+Wikiramblings Light has no rest mass. It does however have Energy. Now, 
you might have heard of Einstein's famous equation E=mc2. The right 
equation is E=γmc2, where γ is Lorentz' 
Transformation: γ=1/(sqrt(1-v^2/c^2)). If you expand γ, you will be left 
with an equation looking like this E^2=m^2*c^4 + p^2c^2. p is momentum! But 
your question remains, right? If momentum is dependent on mass, then it is 
still 0! Well, if mass is 0, the the first term (m^2c^4) disappears and we 
are left with E=p*c. Funny thing is, using Planck's formula to calculate 
Energy: E=h*v, where v is frequency, we do it like so: h*v=p*c (=) 
p=(h*v)/c and considering that c=v*λ (where λ is wavelength) 1/λ=v/c, which 
allows us to arrive to the very simple equation p=h/λ. As you can see, 
light's linear momentum is just Planck's constant devided by its 
wavelength! Very amusing indeed xD Hope I helped you
comments.author: Fred Stork (Malthorin)
